name: Tales of Symphonia
description: FIRST TIME ON STEAM – Based on the PlayStation®3 port of the original GameCube game, this RPG classic is finally available for PC.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista 32/64 Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo 2.4Ghz / AMD Athlon 64 X2 5200+, 2.6GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: Nvidia GeForce 8800GT / ATI Radeon HD 4830 DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 7 GB available space Additional Notes: Gamepad support
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 (x64) / Windows 8 (x64) Processor: Intel Core i3-530, 2.93 GHz / AMD Phenom II X4 940, 3.0GHz Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Nvidia GeForce GTX 560 Ti / AMD Radeon HD 7850 Storage: 7 GB available space Additional Notes: Gamepad support

reviews.review_text: UPDATE : Since this review's getting hits, might as well make it more proper.  This game was launched with many issues, such as:   10-15 second delays when entering settings, save, and load menus   launch times taking upwards of a minute   obvious typos ('contorols')   broken menu alignments   the locked 720p that changes your monitor's resolution (what is this, 2002?)   artifacts of this port being based on the PS3 port   many tutorial dialogs mixing up PS3, Xbox 360 controller, and keyboard controls   and much more  As of this writing only the menu delay seems to be fixed...for me, most of the time. It returned _once_ about 4 hours into a binge, but has otherwise not been an issue. It looks like they're fixing issues but if I were considering to buy this product, I'd wait until they produced a few more updates before actually purchasing this port. It seems the bad press is forcing Namco to act. This is sad, since Zestiria's port was actually pretty good. A little rushed and buggy, but not in any way that disrupted gameplay.  Tales of Symphonia itself is a classic Tales game from 2003, and it's the first ever 3D Tales game. This port is a more or less the remastered PS3 version ported to PC.  Like all Tales games, it uses the Linear Motion Battle System where you move your character in real time across a 2D line on a 3D battlefield -- between yourself and whatever enemy is selected. It plays much like a fighting game or a brawler in that you make real time attacks, perform combos, and need to defend or evade like you would in a brawler. Of course like an RPG, you have 3 other AI controlled party members and you can order them occasionally, but usually they'll just do their own thing. This game's unique gimmicks are Unison Attacks and Overlimits, the former being a bonus attack similar to QTE's and the latter just seems to happen randomly. Unfortunately those Unison Attacks use a PS3 controller interface and I can never seem to get all four to execute.  It's pretty awkward compared to current Tales games...the most notable aspect is this game came out before free roam existed, but while jumping was still an option. So you can't run around to flank enemies, but there are aerial abilities you can perform to achieve the same effect. Having played Phantasia before any others in the series, it wasn't too difficult to pick up on. It's still the awesome battle system that got me hooked on the series.  I had issue with the controls...it might be my 360 controller, but navigating the map was a pain since it uses push sensitivity for walk/run and I'd often find myself walking. It's probably since I'm a PCphile that I settled on using keyboard controls. The default controls are for people whose arms are 3 inches apart, but after switching to WASD + numpad I found gameplay to be pretty enjoyable.  I'm not going to comment on the story until I get further through. 8 hours is too few to judge...but so far it's a mix of a pretty lighthearted party in a pretty bleak world.  Graphics are...720p. They're a notable improvement over the Gamecube graphics but still seem a generation behind for the most part. Also they're quite blurry, being locked at 720 arbitrarily. Bit of a weak point for the game.  The soundtrack is the kind you'd actually make the effort to purchase separately. Not only do I prefer melodic over ambient, I love Motoi Sakuraba's style.  Anyway, I plan on changing my thumbs down into a thumbs up,  but not until this port is fixed.    THERE WAS NO EXCUSE.

Best described as the FF7 of its series, ToS is the one that helped the franchise really breakout in the west. I owned a GameCube, but ultimately decided the console wasn't worth constantly plugging and unplugging and let it gather dust because PS2, so I passed up on this title. Over ten years later, I ended up preordering Zestiria to get the bonus Symphonia and see what the fuss was about.  ToS launched in a deplorable state. Bamco launched the highly anticipated port of one of their most beloved titles as an unstable, buggy mess, which I'm pretty sure violates several Dwarven Vows. Months later, they finally updated it into a workable, playable game that doesn't require a fan-made mod to not be awful (but still helps).  The story initially revolves around a trio of friends: a swordsman named Lloyd, a tolerable child mage named Genis, and Colette, the 'Chosen of Mana'. The mercenary Kratos and their teacher, Raine, soon join up. Colette is foretold to regenerate the world and save humanity from the Desians, half-elves who keep humans in work camps and see themselves as a superier race. The story quickly complicates as more characters appear and the story unfolds.  The battles are real-time. You target an enemy, move away or close the distance. One button allows you to use standard attacks while another uses one of four assigned special attacks depending on whether or not you use it with a directional button. The result is a fast and fun system that allows and rewards combos. The characters you don't control can have their AI customized and specific attacks disabled. Stat growth can also be influenced by assigning 'titles', which are awarded by story events or in-game achievements.  The game starts out sticking closely to its tropes before throwing them out the window. How it bends and twists things were more novel at its launch, but many of them aren't as special now that other games have done the same. The game also doesn't do the best job of hiding some of its twists, or simply foreshadows far too hard. The writing and voice acting is still solid, and certain parts WILL leave you feeling emotional.  The game is stable and plays very well, and TSFix (check the forums) enhances it further. The 30 FPS cap is still annoying, but tolerable. The game has aged well, and I found myself wanting to hurry home so I could resume playing it. I've come to kick myself for not buying it back when it was new. Depsite its initial issues, the current product is enough to make a Tales fan out of me.  shadow and lightning temples can still go to hell though

The official release of this port was a real mess.  Thankfully, Bamco took the whole thing to heart and pretty much fixed all of the issues that plagued this game.  As it is now, there's no slowdown, no graphical hiccups, no more VMPROTECT and it works like charm on my Windows 7. The only major quarrels about it would be the 30 FPS compared to the Gamecube version (But considering this is a port of the PS3 HD version, which was locked on 30 FPS, there's little point in complaining about that) and the fact that using directional arrows on the keyboard to move the character during block puzzles will prevent them from pushing or pulling the blocks, (Still, you can simply change the button config when that happens IF you're using a keyboard). As it is now, the game is perfectly playable and enjoyable in all of its beauty, and I'm glad I was patient enough to have it in working order on my PC after loving it on the Gamecube!
Outdated , I will update the review as soon as I have time to play this game.
I own ToS in the original Game Cube version, the PS3 version, and now here on steam.  This is an unacceptable port. I sincerely wish I hadn't purchased this.

Great game played this alot on gamecube but this port is terrible, FPS lock (WTF? even Gamecube had 60fps) , Internal resolution is locked to 720p and crappy drm is something they have to fix before i can recommend this game.

Ignore all the reviews saying this is bad comparison to the the gamecube/ps2 version. I completed to GC version many a time and ofcourse when this was announced I just had to get it. Playing with a controller it's still lives up to what it was and that makes this game possibly the greatest of all time. Worth playing for all who like a good story with fun combat and lively characters.

Among innumerable other issues, this game was shipped with 3 crippling limitations: 1) VMProtect implementation (FIXED via removal in the latest official path). This intrusive anti-tamperware forced the game to run in a virtual machine, massively slowing down startup times and making unnecessary, constant writes to your disk drive. It also briefly prevented modders from working to fix the issues detailed below. 2) Locked internal resolution of 720p. 3) Locked framerate of 30 FPS.  Namco has yet to do anything about the latter two issues. However, the locked resolution has been resolved by modders in addition to the numerous other improvements they have made. The frame rate, sadly, has yet to see a fix. I'd recommend waiting to buy this until it's genuinely the best version of the game to play, which IMO it won't be until the frame rate limiter has been overcome by the modders, which appears unlikely given the difficulties they have encountered, or patched out by the devs via a miracle.  Oh, and of course, shame to the devs for releasing a port in this state, yadda yadda, they don't care, etc.

Get it for the nostalgia of one of the most amazing RPG's of all time. Don't try to do everything in game 1 tho, you'll burn out. Instead, concentrate on accumulating 8,225 Grade (only if you want ALL the goodies... it'll take awhile, not gonna lia). Then restart on New Game after buying all the goodies in the after-game Grade Shop! Subsequent playthroughs will be much much better... leveling, money making, everything is better in New Game Plus, as long as you have the Grade to buy it! =^_^=

Tales of Symphonia is a JRPG that was first released in 2003 for the GameCube, later ported to the PS2 & PS3, and ported from the PS3 to the PC in 2016.  For a game which is a port of a port it holds up pretty well, at times the controls can feel a bit clunky especially considering you need a relatively fast reaction time during some battle sequences, but they're not a complete disaster.   This game held a fair amount of negative press when it was first ported to PC because the port was done quite poorly. It received a big update in late September which ironed out a lot of the issues which were related to the port (save bugs, slow loading times etc).   As for the game itself, the visuals are decent considering the game is 13 years old, the combat is pretty fun, the soundtrack is quite good and I think the storyline and characters are really solid. The game originally had a lot of bad press on release and was criticised for having a weak plot, but I actually consider it one of the better plots of a game I've played in recent memory.  Overall I'd probably give the game an 8/10. I imagine if I'd played it on the GameCube when it was first released I'd probably give it a 9/10, but the game is still definitely worth playing and is a good installment in the Tales series.
Go emulate the gamecube version, it will run better

I've played this game DOZENS OF TIMES, 100s of hours, on the gamecube version.  This version is *FANTASTIC*. I am up to disc two so far, and the graphics have been STUNNING. This game is so much more gorgeous than it was on the gamecube or the ps3 version.  This is by far my favorite tales game, one of the best games I have ever played. It can never become dull to me and so I am ecstatic that it has found its way to become a computer game with enhanced graphics. Thank you so much steam.

I picked up the game on a whim, i was very hesitant due to the reviews but i gave it a shot.  I played this game years ago on the Gamecube with a friend, we would play every day, over and over. I am glad to say that i have had no issues with this at all so far. The only issue is that it is 30 fps locked, which i can look past for such a fantastic game. 1080p also looks very nice.   I recomend! It seems that most of the issues that people complained about are no longer present, now time to throw 100's of hours into this!

I just finished this game a few minutes ago and here are my thoughs about this game. The Tales series of games always have a great storyline behind them (the main one for me that I hated to play through was Tales of Legendia) and this one is no exception. Once you start playing it, the storyline is very addictive as heck as you want to find out what's going on and who is the true villian to fight. The music was awesome to listen to and all of the characters were all good to play with.  The Controls for this game are surperb. So if you are looking for a great RPG game with a extremely good and immersive storyline then this game is for you.  Now all that we need is for Namco Bandai to release the rest of the Tales series on Steam and to also fix some gramatical issues in this game.
Such a great game but this version keeps crashing!

Is a shame that a great game and gem of RPGs is treated like this when is this game that gave success and established the Tales saga in Occident.  I'm waiting that Bandai Namco fix all the aberrations made to this awesome game.  Just an advice for next ports/releases: BANDAI NAMCO never, never left the port of a great game with high expectations in hands of your Junior Dev Team!!!   This review will change once you fix the game and make it playable again.

I somehow missed this game as a kid despite owning a game cube, but i have been playing it on the free weekend and it's enjoyable as an adult as well.  The combat is tab targeted but fun hack and slash. Despite being able to switch between characters you only seem to be able to play as Lloyd and the charcter switching is for plot reasons, that's fine but if Lloyd dies your other party members will make no atempt to revive and you kind of have to toss orange gel at kratos and hope he kills everyone. I also just recently learned there's a jump function but that's probably more on me.  I've had no problem using this with an xbox 360 controller and the only thing i dislike about it so far is there's no way to speed up the comic book style cutscenes between characters.

(The first hour of gameplay)  - Teacher tells students to stay in class while she investigates some commotion at a tower. - Kids decide that 'No, lets go check it out' - Monsters. - Mysterious Swordman shows up to save them. - Beat the monsters, clear the tower. - Teacher finds the kids at the tower - Teacher spanks one kid and kicks the other one in the face.  10 / 10 Would learn parenting from video games.    One of my favorite games as a kid on gamecube, Story is awesome. Lots of plot twists and character depth and personality for a game that comes off kinda PG-rated. Still remember being awestruck when you find out who Lloyd's real father is, as well as when you find out about how both worlds affect each other. I remember the combat being a lot harder than what my current experience is, but then again, now I'm using blocking and dodging and not just jamming on the attack buttons. The combat is pretty straight forward if you've played any amount of JRPGS. Battles happen in real-time and are not turn based but the battle pauses if you bring up the in-battle item menu or if you're targeting a different enemy - which I like. Also, each weapon actually has its own unique aesthetic when you're in-battle. There are these fire/ice blades you get for Lloyd somewhere near end game and they look badass.   Look at it this way: It released on Gamecube, then they ported it to PS3, and then they ported it to PC.   Obviously this game is ♥♥♥♥ing great.
I can't start the game.  I got this all the way.  ' sec2E03.tmp has stopped working '  What i need to do ? Any idea ?

Don't be fooled by my 0.7 hours; I've beaten the original Gamecube version, and I can definitively say that this is my #1 favorite game. From the characters, to the art style, to the music, to the gameplay, to the story, this game gets everything right.  Except controls. Use a controller and JoyToKey, 'cause keyboard controls for this game are wack. The game was originally designed with a Gamecube controller in mind, and that's definitely reflected in the keyboard controls.  'Favorite game' is completely subjective, so I can't promise you'll like this game, but at least try it for yourself.  The only caveat I have to throw out there is: stay far away from this game's sequel, Dawn of the New World.
A classic, recent patch fixes many issues
What the point to spend money on poorly-ported version on steam when you can play better version for free on Gamecube emulator, huh?
They fixed the choppy framerate issue. Good job guys! My girlfriend loves this game

To start of this is a great game 4.5/5  Pros: Easy to run (you can play this game with a potato of a computer) Great story Amazing battle system Cheap! (I got if for some where around 6$ give or take and I see its 5$ now during the steam winter sale)  Long gameplay, to get a 100% run it would easily take 60 hours minimum  Aged very well, its cartoony characters have made this game a pleasure to keep my eyes on.  Cons:  if you hate rpg's stay away

I have loved this game for the longest time. It's got a great story and I enjoy the combat system. Only problem I've noticed is that some of the voice over sequences are broken. Character A will be speaking, but you hear Character B's voice and it's a 50/50 chance on who's speech bubble appears with the voice.  Also, I would've liked to see something added, maybe like more costumes and the like?

When I first heard that Tales of Symphonia was going to be released for PC, I was very excited! That game was a major part of my teenhood and of the best friendship I've ever had. That game somehow became part of my life, in a minor way. As soon as it was ready to be pre-ordered, I jumped right on it. And when it was finally released, I was so happy! It's been years since I played that game, and I used to lose HUNDREDS of hours on that game because I played through that game so many times and never getting bored of it. Just seeing the intro made me giddy, even though the intro I knew was English, so it was just an instrumental. So in the end, I was very happy this game came here. But then I noticed the reviews, and how people were complaining about how this is a 'horrible port, locked at 30fps and bad graphics' 'we PC gamers deserve the best, not buying this unless best graphics'. And I was just sitting there, facepalming hard... Why are people so damn picky? I'm just glad I can play the game again! I don't care if graphics are bad or crap like that! Just be glad you have it!! I first played it on the Game Cube back in the mid-2000s, of course the graphics aren't going to be like today's AAA games! *sigh* Sorry for venting. This game is absolutely perfect, it has everything you can ever need in a video game. And like every Tales of... games, even though they don't really change with each playthrough, you're gonna want to play it over and over again. So anyways. Thank you so much for putting the effort in making this game available for the PC. I am very grateful.

I am in love with the Tales series and I really hoped that i would get to play this game. You see, because I have a touch screen laptop, this particular game won't play properly for me and it seems that a lot of people are having this issue as well. This is inexcusable in terms of a port, considering I had the option to choose the ps3 version of the port and chose this one instead. A big mistake on my part that I WILL NOT make again! Get it together Bandai Namco!

This was hoestly my favorite game of all time. When I saw that I would be able to play it withoug my gamecube/playstation, I was super pumped. But this game is borderline unplayable. It crashed at the first shop I visited, every time I tried to acess the custom options (which according to everyone else, don't even function when you manage to get past the crash), and now, my computer thinks it's an antivirus. Hell, even when I try to start it with AVG turned off, it still won't load. Im super dissapointed by this. Honestly, the 300 bucks it'd cost for me to get the game on PS3 sounds more efficient than the 20 bucks I spent on this headache. Im honestly, currently looking for an update for this game. If that isn't given to me, or if the game isn't fixed within the next few weeks, I can promise that I will NEVER support a game by this company ever again; which is a shame, cuz Tales of Symphonia is truthfully my absolute favorite game of all time.

With the DRM removed the modders can have a easier time fixing left over bugs that my be present in the game. For the most part even with the DRM VM protect mess the modders were doing a pretty good job. GeDoSaTo and TZFix were both working on this game. Some patch removed the DRM so the game plays as well as it should. There are still a few bugs left over from the porting overall, but at least we have something better to work with.  So the game is a old fav from the Gamecube. My first Tales game, and how I miss it so. It's got a typical story mind you, nothing too special. Most game are like this, it's mainly down to characters, plot, and ideas that mix to make the overall game what it is. I can't wait to play it some more; but I had started finishing some backlogs of games while this one had it's kinks worked out.

Better title for this right now would be Tales of Arkham Knight PC.  For a few weeks, I could play the game as long as I turned off my anti-virus software. Then they patched it. Now even with firewalls off, it still is blocked and is inoperable, due to the fact that it has become a NEW kind of virus-game. Whatever program Bandai-Namco thinks should be active on this game that is causing the virus-like activity, they need to delete it altogether.  Also, they need to fire whoever thought it was a good idea to put it in in the first place.  Edit: Well, they've fixed most of what I was griping about, so, at the risk of quoting Episode One: 'IT'S WORKING! IT'S WORRRKIIIIIINNNNGGG!!!'

Definitely the best JRPG I've ever played, one of the best RPGs I've ever played. My only complaint with the game, is that after playing it, it's made every other RPG I've played feel lacking.  It's still as good as the first time I played it on the Gamecube.  10/10
As far as I'm concerned, I've been meaning to play this for a long time, and the previous complaints of the players were patched during that last patch. I can finally enjoy it properly lol

I loved this game on the Gamecube, and was excited to see a PC port. However, this game runs terribly. No matter what settings you have after a while it just starts to stutter. My PC should be way more than capable of running this, but it becomes unplayable most of the time.

One of my favorite games of all time. For $20, you get well over 100 hours of gameplay. I haven't beaten it yet on the PC, but I've beaten it six times on the Gamecube. The story is really good with lots of unexpected surprises and the soundtrack is pretty good too. I know this review is pretty basic; I hate writing. I couldn't live with myself if I didn't promote this game though.  EDIT: I recommend playing with a controller as the keyboard controls are pretty weird from what I hear.

I'm really happy with how they fixed their initial port of it. Now, keep in mind I nerver played the ps3 version, only the gamecube, so considering that I find the graphics looked awesome and the occasional running into walls I find now aren't even that bothersome given how great it is overall.
Great game, I still have my gamecube version of it. Don't let the negative reviews fool you.

I'm already familiar with Tales of Symphonia (it's a great game) so I'm basing my review on the PC port rather than just the game; that seems to be the trend here.  After reading so many reviews, I was surprised that my eyes didn't explode in my head because of a locked 30 fps. In fact I think the game looks great. Sure it could look better but who cares, Anytime there's glowing reviews of a retro pixel game, it's pretty much unanimously agreed upon that graphics aren't important - it's gameplay and/or story that matters - but as soon as a game is locked at 30 fps everyone is outraged.  I realize that I'm reviewing this game after several patches, and I know that upon the games release, it was kind of a mess, and I know that the original GameCube version looked better, but I don't care. As it is now, I think the game looks and runs great and I have no complaints.   As of this writing, I've only put a half hour into the game, mainly to see how it looked, so there may be plenty of bugs and glitches ahead. If that's true I'll change my review, but I wanted to add my two cents to the uproar about how the game looks.  In short, I think the game looks good and don't feel that that should be a hinderance in anyone's decision to buy it. And I know from past playthroughs that the game itself is great.

Since it's been patched, this port works. It doesn't work particularly well, it offers no graphical customization to speak of, and it really doesn't have any features you'd expect out of a half-decent PC port. I really do love this game, but you're much better off buying the PS3 version that this is a port of. If you don't have a PS3, then I suppose it'll suffice, but don't expect any nice PC features going in.

I just want to say that this port has its downsides, although major ones have been fixed through patching. The game itself has given me the same experience as it did years ago. The only changes I have noticed were things that you could exploit on the older ports. I'm not a good critic and cannot see any problems besides some control issues but the game is controller compatible so it isn't a real problem. (Grabbing boxes is the worst problem I have had with the keyboard)  TL;DR There is no downsides unless you actually try to search for them  and the game holds up to be the same as any other versions.

Seeing how the games malware issue has been resolved, I wanted to keep to my promise and update my review. This is my favorite Tales game of them all, and it pained me to have to give it a negative review. If you're looking for 1080p and 60 fps still, you'll need to mod it but I'm not personally concerned with any of that. It's playable once more by my standards, and is arguably the best of any Tales game out there.
No, they didn't change much to accomadate the computer, but they did a good job preserving the experience. Yes, I say it's a good port, and a great game.

Don't get me wrong i think tales of symphonia is one of the best RPGs out there this port just isn't great its clunky sluggish and absolutely the worst version of it out there if you want to give this game a go get the PS3 version of it. It may not be as good as the gamecube version fp/s wise but is much easier to find Great story, characters and gameplay. You might find the story a bit stock-standard but its over 10 yrs old now so alot of jrpg tropes weren't as abundant then

Updated review after patch:  They fixed the savegame delay, which is a big step. If you can bear the 30 FPS choppiness and 720p resolution, this port is now playable.   The game itself is amazing. All negative reviews here are about the bad port, not the game itself. Decided its good enough for me now to warrant a positive review.
grinded over 200 hours on the gamecube of this gem, just reliving some good memories.  P.S. We want Tales of Phantasia next, the ps1 port please

For the sake of those coming to the reviews wondering if this port of a classic game, one of the best JRPGs of all time, is worth spending 20 dollars on, I can answer succinctly. The answer is not just 'No', with a capital N, but 'HELL NO', in all caps.   If you would like further edification, I will simply post below what I wrote when I requested my refund. But if you need no further information, then I cannot emphasize enough that this game SHOULD NOT BE PURCHASED.  -----  I'm choosing this option ('My issue isn't listed') because this port has too many various, unforgivably terrible issues. It's a game that originally ran on the Nintendo Gamecube at 60 fps, which is now locked at 720p + 30fps. It had numerous crashes and no mouse/keyboard support on launch. These are issues that will likely be fixed in the future but should have been fixed before the game was ever launched.   This is my favorite game from my childhood, and seeing it reduced to this state when I was hoping to relive that experience with at least moderately updated visual quality and new content. I could easily have never bought this and played it on an emulator for that purpose, but I chose to pay for this because I want classic games such as this to continue being ported. What I got instead was a heap of haphazard garbage that even an independent modder could have produced with more quality.  This is an instance of blatant disrespect not just towards the fans and customers, but to their own series. It is clear that there was little to no effort made in producing this port. Since initially it was a 'free' game for pre-ordering Tales of Zestria, why would they waste money improving it, right?  I hope that in the future, Steam will hold its clients accountable for such incredible lack of effort in porting games from console releases. There have already been the catastrophies that Arkham Knight and Mortal Kombat X's launches were, and now another highly significant port has been destroyed by nothing more than gross apathy from the title's owners.  In closing, this is unacceptable garbage. This would unacceptable even if I had received it for 'free' by pre-ordering Tales of Zestria, but asking for twenty dollars for this level of quality is insulting.

VMProtect was removed! Would recommend getting the game and applying TSFix asap though as the port is somewhat bad but not as bad as before.   --------Original Review Pre-Patch 2/29/16--------- The games great but the port is ♥♥♥♥. Still will play it but after my playthrough is finished i'll just stick with my gamecube.
♥♥♥♥ port! stay away! or refund! they need to learn.

I really wish steam had a Neutral option but ill give my opinion best I can  **READ THIS** If you have windows 7 dont bother with the game, so many issues. If like me you have windows 8, 8.1 or 10 you should be fine.  PROS: + Game runs well on low end rigs + Dual audio +Controller support (I use a 360)  CONS: - No graphical settings besides resolution - Terrible lip sync - People only speak on main events or sections - Bad port in general (Windows 7 users are hit the hardest ) - Capped to 30 fps (I dont care but you might)  I got the game for free and I will probably finish it but I wont be in a hurry for hours and hours of playtime. My only experience with tales was Tales of zesteria and I loved it, Im sure the game is good but its a bad port that brings it down.

Possibly my favourite gamecube game (which is saying something from a console with two zeldas and the metroid prime series.) This is an Insulting Port, terrible frame rate, missing effects from the gamecube version, internal resolution locked at 720p, 2 minutes plus to access the options memory due to a freeze (apparently caused by DRM), a minute to save at save points due to freeze. For £14.99 this should be a definative port, not a cynical cash grab. Not worth the money, am getting a refund. Pure garbage.

Tales of Symphonia is an amazing game, and one of my favorite RPGs of all time. That being said, this port isn't up to snuff. I enjoy it none the less, but I shouldn't lie to people just because of my blind nostalgia. There are many issues with this port that hinder the game experince. Personally I don't care about the 30fps vs. 60fps stuff, so it running in 30 doesn't bother me, but I know it will others. Also, this game is only native 720p. Again, something I don't really mind, but others will. These are fairly minor compared to the countless bugs though, so buy at your own risk or wait until the issues are resolved.

Controls a little clunky and it's hard to figure out what you're doing. But other than that a really classic game with a fun combat system and a storyline that's kept me engaged (that's fairly hard to do).
So much nostalgia with this game. I remember just replaying this over and over on the gamecube~  Great storyline and fun characters.

Not the best port, but Durante's fix helps solve the most crippling issues with resolution, character outlines and stuttering. The 30FPS lock seems to be an unfixable issue, but considering this is a straight port from the PS3 (which in turn is a port from the PS2), it kinda sucks that they couldn't take that cap off. This is PC gaming, Namco. You don't have to cheap out by making a straight console port and changing almost nothing. The GameCube ran this game better 13 years ago, but it's still playable at 30FPS, albeit nowhere near as crisp as the GCN release. At the end of the day, this is still Tales of Symphonia, and it's a fantastic game in a beloved and underrated series that everyone should play. But if you can, try to get this game at a reduced price- the GameCube original is still somewhat reasonably priced these days, and $20 for this port just seems too steep for such a cheap port.
30 fps lock. After terrible and hard beginning the game becomes quite enjoyable. Not bad for a port of a port of a game from 2003.

First of all, I used to play it on Gamecube, so I have a lot more hours of playtime than this. It's much closer to 500 hours or so. :)  This is one of the few games that I'm never tired of playing. After all this time, I still discover new things to do and new places to explore. There is a lot of stuff to do in this game and achieving everything in this game will require some time.  The story is deep and wonderful, the characters are beautiful and very interesting, the music is brilliant and the gameplay is fun and addicting. The graphics are definitely not the best but graphics is not everything in a game. Everything else is so powerful in this game that you don't give a damn about the graphics and you just keep playing it. o/  If you're a rpg fan like me and especially Jrpgs, you'll love this game! You REALLY have to play it! It's the best one in the Tales of series so you can't miss it if you are a fan of the series.  So go buy the game, you'll not regret it! :D

Came to see this game by watching my friend stream this on steam. To my first time, it is quite enjoyable. My interest in the game with the storyline, the plot, and also the characters. I fell in love with right away! I told myself I had to buy this game which I have done today. Thank you for bringing this game onto steam. I really am enjoying it so far. :3 I didn't have any dislikes for the game. I noticed how hard it can be if you don't have the right equipment. XD Still this game for me was one of the best out there. I love games like these and hope for morein the future. I recommend those who love adventure like rpg games to buy this for yourself and experience for yourself.

This is likely one of the best RPG games a person can play on a screen. While some people might not compare it to today's art and animation, this game will blow almost any modern game out of the water for story content. When compared to other modern games, it feels like the creators focused on the story first rather than last. Not to say the game has bad art or system controls, quite the opposite really. From the fight system to the world map the game comfortable and the controls for moving, fighting, and navigating the menus is too simple not to grasp. The characters don't look as blocky as some might expect, and capture the actual character's design beautifully. The in menu art is simply amazing, not much else to be said about it.  The game has great art, great story, and great form, and will make an excellent addition to any story lover's library. Any person who loves story will love this game, as this isn't some game you'll beat in a day of playing. Even knowing where everything was and ignoring the optional content, it took me nearly 38 hours to beat the game. Going through the game looking for all that extra stuff, completing all the things you can, this game can extend well over 150 hours.  While true that the New PC version has a few issues, they are easily fixed. For those who find it crashing on start up, simply run the game as the administrator and you're home free!  This is a treasure, and it brings me great joy to see it brought back.

Loved this game. I wouldn't say that it is not playable despite all the issues surrounding it in the mean time. It's a bad port, we get it. You can review the /actual/ game. 30fps, 720p lock. So what? It's still a game that you can play. I've never experienced any crashes, even after finishing the game. I'd recommend the game if you really could care less about 30 fps and a 720p res lock.

Just another garbage Namco Bandai PC port. 30 FPS lock looks atrocious, 720p is whatever, but there's some really ♥♥♥♥ video compression ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t in the opening, WHICH MAKES NO SENSE. When playing full screen, never alt tab, cause it will crash. Don't try to stream this, cause the DRM (I don't know why this needs such specific DRM?) will make it launch a different EXE every time you start it, so Window Capture is requird.  The only positive feature of this version? It has the Japanese Opening.  This is a very depressing port of my favorite game of all time. Please save your money.

I'm not sure what the huge deal is with the bad review still. I haven't had any problems with this so far. Though I had a brief scare in the Toize Valley Mines. I had cleared it, went back to go and talk to that Gnomelette 1 thing and when I was heading back, I didn't see the A button (playing with an Xbox 360 controller) show up. And I kept going down left and then my character disappeared but I could still move. I moved my character out and then back and it showed up finally.  I've had this for a few weeks now and I'm getting ready to explore the Earth Temple. Liking the new Techs that I've gotten so far and trying to get Collette's Grand Cross. Then whatever else after that.

If you never played this on the gamecube years ago. you never experienced the original. this is JUST as good espescially if you are using an Xbox Controller, This game is one of the BEST Rpgs on Steam. the controls are easy to do and the battle controls are simaler to smash bros to be honest. The story has multiple routes you can take was make different Results depending on decisions you make. THIS GAME IS AWESOME!

The patch fixed most of the problems, and they stated that they will fix the other problems in patches to come. I would recommend it now regaurdless of all the negitive reviews. You guys need to stop ♥♥♥♥♥ing, it plays without crashing now, the delay when opening menues and saving has been fixed, and they are currently working on the rest of the complaints
You'll spend most of your play time waiting for the damn NPCs to get out of the way.

Now that the game is working (for me) I am quite happy.  Playing the PS3 and GC version like a crazy man I know that I really like the story and its twists.  + finally working (what a sad, sad plus, but oh well) + good story + additional stuff (new attacks, enemies, sidequests etc) because they used the PS2 version + co-op, local + dual audio (skits will obly be voiced in Japanese though)  * real time battles (that is one of the reasons I like this series) * you really have to search in order to find all the (missable) sidequests and so on  - 30 FPS, not that I have problem with that, but I know some people will and I could I would use 60. - still no resolution fix (official one)
In my opinion, among one of the best JRPGs of all time.

I know the game isn't exactly working the greatest as its just became a new port to steam earlier this month, but after playing around with the keyboard controls, the block you move in Martel Temple, you have to hold the Start Button (Use according to what yours is set to), and THEN move it. I stopped playing for a bit because of this bug, but afterwards continued once I found out for myself. Definitely recommend playing using an actual controller though. The game itself has a great storyline and many promising challenges.

i really like the Tales of games Symphonia was the best story but this isnt a port from the ps3 its the port from ps2 the ps2 was locked on 30fps the GameCube was lock on 60 fps in 2003 how come they used the ps2 version and not the GC  lets hope for a Patchs or a Pc Genie that will mob the shiznizel out of this
until know there is no error.  its playing well

This game is just too good to be rating it negatively. Yes the port had some very glaring issues, but official patches already fixed the most glaring issues (especially the language ones), and then the user mods did the rest. There seems to be a 60fps mod on its way as well, so honestly there's no way to keep giving this game thumbs down anymore. This is one of the better games in the Tales series, as well one of the most iconic JRPGs of its generation, and it still holds up to this day. If you're into the genres, by all means this is the game for you. If you haven't tried any JRPGs before then this is a very good starting point. If you straight up hate JRPGs then I guess avoid this one: the story is very much fond of the genre's cliches, but the Tales of battle system made one of its biggest improvements in this titles, so action and fighting games fans might just feel right at home with its combo system (which admittedly requires you to invest some time and leveling up in order to get to the good parts of it).  I know many people who played this back in the day and are sitting this port out due to the technical issues. To them I say that now it's fine to step in and buy the game.  To those who have never played this before, I can only suggest to play it once on their own. And then play it over and over again (perhaps following guides from the second time around), because there are many things to do here, even missables and all, and I always found this to be one of the most replayable games out there despite its length.

As of today with the mod fixes, This game is definitely a must get, With all settings cranked up it easily surpasses any version out there making this almost the definitive version. No stutters, 1080P graphics, Smooth battle transitions. If it was full price i would pay for it. All i have to do now is wait for that 60 fps patch and i would ranked this up high along with the fully modded 60fps Tales of Zestiria.

This is a poorly done port of an amazing game. I am going to enjoy playing through it again. My PS3 is aging, so this is my likely go-to version of the game despite the 720p @ 30fps lock. Once you get past that, it's still Tales of Symphonia, and amazing.
I have a Windows 10, and the game crashes randomly a lot. Which is a shame, because I like it. If this is patched, I would recommend the game.
Never gets old. Best Tales game still to this day.
This is my childhood right here.

EDIT: Thanks to some wonderful people of the community, a mod is available to change the opening theme back to the original western GCN release. A big thanks goes out to the people that shared the file and made me aware of it.  The game itself is amazing, technical issues aside, and I really can't recommend it enough. There have been enough patches now that the game is more in line with what it should have been at release.  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  THEY CHANGED THE OPENING THEME FROM THE GAMECUBE VERSION. SOMEONE FIX THIS PLEASE.  Still a great game though. But that opening theme was the best ever.  Mixed feelings/10
Accidently had the AI set to auto.... lost the first fight. Was met with the Game Over Screen 10/10 AI

Tales of Symphonia is my favorite game of all time. Which is why it's so hard for me to give this game a thumbs down for now.  Yes, I very much dislike that it's at 30 FPS. That's not a deal breaker for me, though. I trust a mod will fix it. The deal breaker is the textures. Everything is extremely blurry and the game crashes constantly, especially when trying to change settings or open the Steam overlay. I expect this game to be fixed via modding, but for now, I'd stay away. It's not a pleasant experience :(

Works for me now i don't mind the 30 FPS lock but i wish there will be a patch that unlock that FPS limit, if not then i will use fanmade mod to unlock it no big deal.   Oh boy Bandai Namco really put an effort to fix it because the first release performance and port is a huge mess. They really patch it and now some of the problems are fixed and i really appreciate that Bamco listen to our feedback and fix it right away.  but still they need to fix the 720p Resolution, add graphical setting, and increase the save slot * 10 or 20 would be enough *  Overall this is a great game for JRPG fan especially Tales series fan. I used to play it and spend hours with my old PS2 but sadly my PS2 broke before i got to the last arc. I'm glad i can play it again on my PC and Laptop  One of my top 5 Tales games of all time and one of my top 10 RPG of all time. Probabbly the most well paced Tales game out there.       Minor Spoiler here   I still shipped Llyod x Sheena damn it !!!! :( :( :(
I simplay can't recommend a game that crashes every time you press alt-tab. Also tends to crash then you click your mouse buttons.

The port is bad.  For all of you who have access to the Gamecube or PS2/3 versions of the game, play that instead.  I'm no dev, and I don't know why they be dumb, but I still really like this game and am happy to have this on my big picture collection, even if it's a worse version then what I played over 10 years ago.  And if even though I'm giving this a positive review, please do not take it lightly when I say it's a bad port. I've spent 100s of hours on the GCN version with multiple playthroughs, the 30FPS is very hard to get use to, even if I haven't played this game in years.

A lot of people have been reporting difficulties and issues with opening the game up. I had no such issues, but that may have been because of a patch I missed. You can rebind your keyboard controls which is cool for keyboard users and supports 360 controller fully, even having the correct buttons on screen. At a constant 30 FPS for a low-tier machine, the game is still incredibly smooth. So smooth that if someone tinkered with files to put it to full 60 FPS it would make the game not break, but not look good. If you have played a Tales game before, the combat will feel familiar to you. Story is take it or leave it. I personally have no issue with it, the typical hero must go on a journey to save the world, etc. The english voiceovers are well done, something the Tales game is pretty solid at with each game, however you can choose Japanese voiceovers if you want to.  Cons: -Everything looks a bit too large in terms of proportions (as in the models, the world, etc.) -The story if you don't care for it. Pros: -Runs smoothly -No major gamebreaking bugs have been reported. -Combat is fun and intuitive. -Opens up fine for me, but seems to be a common issue. -High customizable controls for both controller and keyboard. -English voiceovers are well done.  In my opinion, this is a very well done port, and for 20 bucks is worth it. At the very least, worth trying it out.

Don't be fooled by the hours I have currently, i have played this on the PS3.   I understand why the game is getting so many negative reviews, as the actual port itself of this game is severly lacking in what you would expect of a pc port. However, if you are someone who doesn't care if a game can or can't show off your RIG (You should probably get a controler as well), you should definitely get this game. It's one of the best in the series, with an intriguing story, good combat, good characters. Just come into the game expecting a gamecube game, it is originally one after all

Avoid it until someone in the community makes a 60FPS patch. It's abominable that the original Gamecube version ran at that pace, but the later PS3 version at 30 (which was a mass complaint about that version) and despite that they didn't bother resolving this for this release.  On the Gamecube this was one of my favorite releases of all time, but the PS3 version just feels like Bandai Namco slogged it through the mud.

Unlike some of the others reviewing this, I have had no issue with the resolution, and currently have it set to 1920x1080. Much like Tales of Zestiria, the first PC 'Tales of' game, the framerate is locked at 30fps.  There appears to be no mouse support, yet the mouse still is visible in fullscreen mode.  Startup time is a bit long, and the game hangs whenever accessing the Save, Load, and Customize(options) menus, both from the title screen or while playing. Don't think it crashed, it has taken up to a minute for me to load any one of these menus(and on a PC that can flawlessly run Tales of Zestiria on max). All other menus appear to have no issues, both in and out of combat. With the exception of the initial startup and those three menus, the game load times are as fast as expected.  I enjoy that they included the original theme/opening, rather than the one that the US received in the GameCube release, and the presence of the Japanese voiceovers is nice.  As a long time JRPG player, and a long time fan of the 'Tales of' series, with Tales of Symphonia being my favourite, I would highly recommend Tales of Symphonia to anyone that loved the GC or PS3 release, anyone who enjoys other 'Tales of' games, and to anyone that loves a good JRPG with an amazing storyline.  I myself can't wait to get the chance to just sit down and dive back into Sylvarant, and head off to regenerate the world.

loved this game when i spent 1000+ hours on it for game cube and am so happy i get to play it again  i have seen people having issues with the game and blew it out of perportion... the only issues i had with it yesterday was that it took 30+seconds to load the save/load menu's and once my friend started chatting with me when i went to open the steam overlay the game would crash. the load time is instant now and i turned off the steam overlay for the game alttabing doesnt hurt the game at all and i havnt had any issues with with the frame rate i changed it to 1080x1920 and it looks as good as i remember it being i have taken screenshots of the opening and will take some of gameplay later   the only thing i notised is missing is the character description bio thingy unless im missing something  i am happy with this re release and the outrageous hate on the quality pushed an update to make it better

I have been a fan of this game for over 10 years. This game changed my life when I discovered it and I have very fond memories of playing this game with my brother back when it first came out on Gamecube. . This is my third time buying Tales of Symphonia and I can't wait to dive right back into this fantastic JRPG.  This is by far my favorite videogame of all time.   My only complaint is that it feels weird playing this game without a controler. I am not sure if I can handle playing this with just my keyboard.
Just wait for the fixes and it will be worth it.
Awesome game,  Never played it before, reminds me of Phantasia a lot. Haven't ran into any bugs or problems(running on AMD hardware/windows 10)  highly recommened

one of the best tales series and magically it work and perform perfectly in pc i really recommend it to everyone  great story = 9/10  unique gameplay system = 8.5/10  great graphic = 8/10  overall = 9.5/10  that is my personal opinion you can watch youtube video and decide for yourself
My favourite game. It has great, lovable characters, a ton of sidequests and different paths to take, and the combat is something I personally enjoy. It also has a really nice soundtrack.
the game is so great, nice porting. not see a bug yet except english voice not sounding in mine.

EDIT: The game has been pached to address issues that people had, and it has made the game a LOT more playable! The framerate is still 30fps, but it has been optimized and smoothed to a point where it honestly doesn't even feel 30fps. The game also looks a lot better after this update, pretty much as good as you can get a 12 or so year old game to look.  Tales of Symphonia is still a game I recommend to people to get them started in the Tales series. It's one of the series' defining games. It's incredibly fun to play, and the story is engaging right from the start.  That being said, it's by no means perfect. It lacks a lot of features that make later games even better. Despite the battles taking place on a 3D plane, there's no free movement, as you're restricted to an X axis between you and the enemy you're targeting. The story, while it's pretty good, isn't as polished as a lot of the other series' games. It's also packed with plot twists, almost to a fault. The game in general just really shows its age. It's a dated game. But it's still an essential part of the Tales series.  tl;dr if you can't stand games made over a decade ago then don't play

Initial Impressions.  Some Configurations are located in a text file to change if you like Windowed mode.  Locked at 30 FPS but not really bothered, what is bothering me right now.  There are currently some issues with Windows 7 as reported but no problems with Windows 8.  Using a Logitech controller with no issues.   Still checking

SO then where to begin i first played this game so so long aog on game cube and its ben well over 10 years and i can finaly play a classic jrpg one everyone should consider getting. story is great pretty dishearting as it progresses tho you will see why soon
I tried the free weekend. It was awful. My only regret is that I played the game.

Wait for additional patches and bug fixes before purchasing. This is a mess right now.  Edit: Status November 2016 a lot of things have been fixed; personally I havn't tested yet whether they improved the game up to the point you do not need to use 3rd party applications like Kaldaien's or Durante's GeDoSaTo to enjoy a good game here, but I'll change my review to positive for now. At least they changed the terrible management of save slots.

Great JRPG that brings back memories. From what I can see most complaints were because of bugs. In my 31 hours of playing game, I experience not a single bug, everything was smooth and without crushing or corrupted save files.  By the look of the game you might think that the story and characthers are childish, but in fact story is very deep and complex, questioning religion, racial racism and it is perfectly applied to our modern world. Charachters are great and complex, although maybe the main Lloyd is kinda stereotyped. :)  Gameplay is classical for that time, there is always dungeon with light puzzle elements (that ar becoming fairly harder towards the end of the game), every dungeon is filled with enemies that are made with great imagination and it is joy to fight them . After completing dungeon, in most time u go visit new city where stoy untold and u can purchase new weapons, armors and items and explore it.   Fight in battle is 2D, where you control 1 characthers, other 3 are via AI, or u can manually make them use certain spells an abilities. I didnt find game hard, so maybe battle can become more like button smashing, but i never felt bored or tired due to great looks of enemies, splashy spells and that ultra mega combo attacks that looks awesome :D .  I could spend easily more than 50 hours , but I didnt have time to do sidequests, or to get most powerful weapons and to explore every place on the map.  Overall this is awesome game that is worh every cent, and I just can hope we will get more of JRPG, the old one with remastered/remake versions, and also new one that can make use of new technologies

I played this game mercilessly in my younger years. I beat it several times in a row (6), because I absolutely adored the story and characters.  As a port, I avoided this title, knowing it would be bad. I was smart. Once the problems had been mostly fixed, I installed and started playing. As good as I remember!
Game is good. Better then Vesperia

Tiny Gene, a pus moleculant, traveling fast along the micro-tubule channel, mega-fast, and faster to get to the work site. The great dome covered the entire city, and the twin towers looked beautiful frozen in the polaroid photograph amber gel of the pimple plaza. Gene broke through the meating room doors, and locked eyes with his superior, hiding behind a slab of bloody venison. 'Late again Gene', Bloat spewed, giving Gene a snarky but mysterious grin. 'Today is the day for the explosion of meat.' Gene was shocked and stood still but imagined himself falling through five thousand paper cut-outs in the floor. 'I had a feeling it was coming; My disgusting fat arms were swaying unusually this morning, during my routine, that I do, in the morning, before work.' Suddenly, a giant metal pin poked through the O-Zone above the city and the amber protect-o-gel began to diffuse through the tiny hole. With this, the towers were uprooted, their bright yellowish white marble crumpling, and the boys were smashed between the dried mud track sheets of floor 21 and the ceiling of floor 20, their bloody boogy bodies stricken. Jake's pus sac finally got popped. The pus covered the bathroom mirror again, just as his mother started calling for him. 'Jake, you better not be chokin' your tiny little baby chicken again! It's surely supper time. . . .', she said. 'No! I was thwarting this giant menace pimple sac that had been placed upon mine chimple by some type of lesser demon! I will be down for eatings soon mother. Do not fret.' And Jake exited the bathroom.
Well worth a playthrough.

A fun RPG series that takes many hours, both in the main storyline and in the side quests. Combat is fairly complex especially due to the customization that is afforded for the individual's style and needs, not to mention the many of characters you can play as along with the multiplayer aspect. Graphics aren't anything special but this is a port of a game originally released in Gamecube. Storyline is quite entertaining but that is pretty subjective.
p gud if you don't mind a frame skip every so often ( about twice in a few hours on my end ), worth it for the nostolgica.

I guess the game was a mess at launch, but seems to have been fixed since. The only negative I can say about the port is the horrible 'blur' effect, which can be remedied quite easily by downloading and installing the TSfix mod. Other than this minor complaint, the game itself is really great. At this point in time, it's totally worth the $20 Namco is asking for, even if the port isn't 100% perfect.
So much Nostalgia <3 using a keyboard tends to be hard but I'm going to invest in a controller. Otherwise, the mechanicsof the game are exactly as I remember it, and I still love this game so much

Where to begin this was my fisrt time playing the tales game and man i am addicted. i love it i know the port is not 60fps but i love it  the battle's are great story is cool i love it it was worth my money
One of the best games out there, play it if you can and play with a group of friends if you can also.

As to the story, gameplay, content of this legendary JRPG classic: What is there to say... it is still every bit as lovely and wonderful as the day I first played it, and it immediately makes me feel like a kid again upon hearing the BGM and seeing those characters again.  Now on PC, we finally have the ability to play this game at a level of visual fidelity that has never been seen before - I especially recommend using the Special K Install Manager (just google it) to easily get access to 4k textures, the original, much darker and noticeable character borders, UI cleanups and more in the form of easily downloadable and completely free 'DLC'!

One of my favorite JRPG's growing up. The characters are fun, the plot starts somewhat generic but deepens as it goes on, and the combat is dated by Tales standards but still tight and action packed. The port is a lot better now than it was at launch, but still be sure to pick up Kaldaien's fix in the forums. Thankfully he's here to do what Bandai Namco couldn't be bothered to.

I have very fond memories of playing the original version of this classic RPG on the GameCube at my best friend's house in the months leading up to both of us graduating high school. Needless to say, I was hooked from the get-go. Everything was awesome. However, I will admit the battle system took me by surprise. I was still used to turn-based systems at the time, so the real-time battles threw me off. But then I started treating the battles more like a fighting game and persevered.  The thing that struck me most about this game is how much raw detail they go into exploring just how horribly prejudice and bigotry affects all the people involved in it, not just the ones who are the targets of said victimization. They even show that the Big Bad is someone who had the most heroic ideals at first, then became corrupted into something really horrifying and twisted. You even feel sorry for him by the end of things, which is a really deep storytelling move most games (or hell, most story-telling mediums period) don't delve into very much, because we want to keep deluding ourselves that things are black-and-white.  Another thing that struck me about the game is that despite how bright and colorful the game appears, it's still a pretty dark story. There's part of the story that are dilebrately shown in the game to overtly convey how crappy things are, such as the human ranches. But there's other things in the subtext of the game that if you really think about it, you're like 'Cripes, this is ♥♥♥♥ed up ♥♥♥♥ that they're doing. Why wasn't anything done to stop it before?!'.  Anyway, when I found out this game was coming to Steam, I was delighted. Especially when I found out it was based on the PS3 version, which I could never get. Why 'especially'? Because the PS3 version was based on a then Japan-only PS2 port of the game which had additional stuff put into it, from costumes to story details which weren't in the original GCN version.  Now, I should go on record and say that I purchased this game on Steam the day it came out for full price because I wanted it so much. I also had Windows 7 at the time. It worked perfectly, even when I set it up to be played in a window, I also managed to record a first impressions video of it, which you can find on my profile if you're interested. *cough*shameless self-promotion*cough* Anyway, I was blown away by how much crisper the game looked to me. The game text was also a bit easier to read. The voice acting and localization were still top-notch.  Basically, if you want an RPG where they deconstruct the notion of a 'Chosen One' and also have both the heroes and villains alike are morally complex than they first appear, this game has that in spades. Hell, if you love RPGs, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try.  Also, ignore the initial reviews of this port, because I feel like they're just being resentful that it doesn't have the specs they wanted, like 60FPS, which hardly makes a difference in my mind. The game still plays well, and that's what truly matters at the end of the day.
this is a great game and i have never played any games in the tales series its a most have if you love JRPGs
